#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Improve Communication Within a Globally Distributed Team
#Text=Communication plays an essential role in software development .
#Text=In the first month of a project , developers spent over 50 % of their time on group work. .
#Text=When working in a globally distributed team , communication becomes more of a challenge due to the lack of face-to-face meetings .
#Text=Communication in globally distributed teams has “ a critical role in the success of a team ” and can be “ the largest source of problems . ”
#Text=This wikiHow will provide an overview of the best practices for communication in a globally distributed software team to help you avoid common mistakes .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Improving General Communication
#Text=Have teams meet in person at an early stage of the project .
#Text=When starting a project , it is highly recommended to define standardized processes and establish shared knowledge .
#Text=You can do this by doing a physical kick-off meeting with all teams involved at the start of a project .
#Text=Studies show that this increases inter-team performance dramatically. .
#Text=If you are only using online tools , it may not be enough .

#Text=Another advantage meeting in person provides is that it gives you a common understanding of requirements which in the long run will cut down project costs and enables your teams to better react to changes within them .
#Text=Proactively check the status of teams .
#Text=Since your teams are operating independently , there is a risk that some of them might deviate from the initially agreed upon plan .
#Text=These deviations can have a major impact on the other teams and therefore on your whole project .
#Text=If you pro-actively check the status of all teams on the overall project , you can ensure all teams are always aligned .
#Text=Assign a ‘ communication manager ’ responsible for the communication between the teams .
#Text=In order to prevent miscommunication between the teams , you can appoint one person to coordinate the communication .
#Text=This ‘ human facilitator ’ has the goal of providing smooth communication and reducing conflicts .
#Text=It is important that this facilitator is not biased and both teams feel comfortable communicating with this person .
#Text=It can even be helpful to have a key member of one team physically located with the other team .
#Text=Introduce avenues for informal communication between the teams .
#Text=In addition the formal communication , there is generally also a lot of informal communication between colleagues .
#Text=Think of conversations at the coffee machine .
#Text=It turns out that developers spent an average of 75 minutes per day on unplanned interpersonal communication .
#Text=In these small conversations , team members become aware of what is happening and what issues are being encountered within the project .
#Text=The challenge is to simulate these casual encounters in a digital environment .
#Text=One solution is to get all of your teams members on a video call and just let them chat away .
#Text=Choose the right communication tool .
#Text=Communication tools can be divided into two groups : Synchronous and asynchronous .
#Text=Synchronous communication requires both parties to be available at the same time , this includes video calling and live chats .
#Text=Asynchronous communication does not have this requirement and includes tools like e-mail .
#Text=Choosing which type of communication is needed depends on the goal of the communication .
#Text=Synchronous communication is preferred when reaching an agreement is the goal , since it is highly interactive .
#Text=Asynchronous communication is fit for highly technical discussions that include detailed content such as source code .
#Text=The asynchronous communication allows the parties to take their time to understand the content before responding .
#Text=Despite the points mentioned above , it is important to allow your teams to choose their own tools without forcing anything on them .
#Text=They know what is best for them .
#Text=Enhancing Communication Via Automation
#Text=Use automation to communicate effectively .
#Text=Automation not only makes the process run faster , but it is also a very effective way to communicate precisely with others to understand how the task or process should be executed .
#Text=This is useful when working in distributed environments ; you can make use of automation to bridge the gaps .

#Text=Process automation like building software , testing , etc. eliminates human errors , configuration drifts , and communication misunderstandings , which helps people focus more on feature development .
#Text=Do not create a separate , siloed automation team .
#Text=When working in a distributed environment , it is easy to offshore all the automation work , like test automation and infrastructure automation , to other teams or countries .
#Text=Most companies follow a pattern of building features and software onsite and then moving the automation work to an offshore team .
#Text=However , this does not work in practice , as only specific teams will have to knowledge of how the automation works .
#Text=This causes a more bureaucratic silo and is eventually is followed by a blame-game of teams when an error is caused .
#Text=Follow the same coding guidelines and testing guidelines for automation .
#Text=You should follow specific coding guidelines and testing guidelines , because it makes sure that the right message is passed from the development team to the business .

#Text=Since automation code is also production code , you need to maintain the same quality checks and standards that you use to maintain the production code , or else the testing code becomes harder to maintain in the long run ; the team will eventually lose focus and interest as it is difficult to maintain automation .
#Text=Create a framework or set up tools to promote people to talk to each other frequently .
#Text=Every team member should be able to track and review any new technical decisions or requirements changes such as build failures or refactoring .
#Text=You can use tools like TFS , Github , JIRA , Slack , or Trello , which show who ’s accountable for each task and help developers to have a reference to add in data where it was last completed .
#Text=This ensures teams at different locations know what is going on .
#Text=Practice continuous integration and continuous delivery .

#Text=Practicing an automated deployment pipeline ensures that teams at different locations are working towards a common goal and can work more integrated which results in better communication between distributed teams .
#Text=This also reduces the time required to manually review and wait for decisions .
#Text=Sharing information helps all the teams understand the objectives and aids communication and productivity .
